bestBHT.bht: Before the world existed, the Son of God had glory with the Father. This perfect reciprocity of services between the Son and the Father is expressed in this quote, as the Son prays to be received back into that glory. It is a decisive proof of the unity of Christ's three estates: eternal pre-existence in glory, humiliation in the flesh, and glorification in the Resurrection Body. By praying for full restoration to the pre-incarnate glory and fellowship, Jesus affirms his actual and conscious existence at the Father's side.

Henry Alford: The same Person who had with the Father glory before the world, also glorified the Father in the world, and prays to be again received into that glory."
A decisive proof of the unity of the Person of Christ, in His three estates of eternal pre-existence in glory, humiliation in the flesh, and glorification in the Resurrection Body."

This direct testimony to the eternal præ-existence of the Son of God lias been evaded by the Socinian and also the Arminian interpreters, by explaining the word had to mean, 'possessed by Thy decree which destined it for Me.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: A PERFECT RECIPROCITY OF SERVICES of the Son to the Father first, and then of the Father to the Son in return, is what our Lord means here to express.
With this pre-existent glory, which He veiled on earth, He asks to be reinvested, the design of the veiling being accomplished.
Not, however, simply as before, but now in our nature.
Albert Barnes: With thine own self - In heaven, granting me a participation of the same honor which the Father has.
With the glory - With the honor. This word also includes the notion of happiness, or everything which could render the condition blessed.
Before the world was - There could not be a more distinct and clear declaration of the pre-existence of Christ than this.
Marvin Vincent: With Thyself [παρα σεαυτω] . In fellowship with Thyself. So with Thee [παρα σοι] .
John Calvin: He desires to be glorified with the Father...that every knee may bow to him."
He now declares that he desires nothing that does not strictly belong to him, but only that he may appear in the flesh, such as he was before the creation of the world.
This is a remarkable passage, which teaches us that Christ is not a God who has been newly contrived, or who has existed only for a time; for if his glory was eternal, himself also has always been.
Philip Schaff: The prayer is that the clouds which during His earthly life had obscured the glory of His Divine Sonship may be rolled back.
The word ‘glory,’ in short, is to be understood in the sense of glory to be manifested as well as in a sense expressing the contents of the glory.
Not the Son’s personal exaltation, but the Father’s glory through the Son’s, is still the keynote.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus prays for full restoration to the pre-incarnate glory and fellowship... This is not just ideal pre-existence, but actual and conscious existence at the Father's side.
It is small wonder that those who deny or reject the deity of Jesus Christ have trouble with the Johannine authorship of this book and with the genuineness of these words.
But even Harnack admits that the words here and in verse John 17:24 are 'undoubtedly the reflection of the certainty with which Jesus himself spoke.'
John Gill: The glory Christ prays for is ... the glory which I had with thee before the world was.
This is not to be understood of the glory of the human nature of Christ, abstractly considered ... but he did not really and actually exist as man, until he took flesh of the virgin.
This designs the glory of him as Godman, and Mediator; he was not only predestinated to be a Mediator, but was really set up as such from everlasting.
John Wesley: The glory which I had — He does not say received - He always had it, till he emptied himself of it in the days of his flesh.

bhtAttempts.bht: Before the world existed, the Son of God had glory with the Father. This perfect reciprocity of services between the Son and the Father is expressed in this verse, as the Son prays to be received back into that glory. It is a decisive proof of the unity of Christ's three estates: eternal pre-existence in glory, humiliation in the flesh, and glorification in the Resurrection Body. By praying for full restoration to the pre-incarnate glory and fellowship, Jesus affirms his actual and conscious existence at the Father's side. Those who deny his deity struggle with these words, but their genuineness is certain, as they reflect the certainty with which Jesus himself spoke.
